message.content:
Step 1: Calculate the Current Ratio.
• Total Current Assets = 9,891,156.92 
• Total Current Liabilities = 631,880.98 
• Current Ratio = 9,891,156.92 / 631,880.98 ≈ 15.65

Step 2: Calculate the Quick Ratio.
Quick assets exclude inventory. Sum the quick items:
• Cash on Hand = 2,339,224.10 
• Bank Deposits = 4,292,000.00 
• Interest Receivable = 14,796.43 
• Accounts Receivable = 2,902,136.39 
Quick Assets = 2,339,224.10 + 4,292,000.00 + 14,796.43 + 2,902,136.39 = 9,548,156.92 
• Quick Ratio = 9,548,156.92 / 631,880.98 ≈ 15.12

Step 3: Calculate the Debt to Asset Ratio.
Assuming the only debt comes from current liabilities:
• Total Debt = 631,880.98 
• Total Assets = 14,799,664.61 
• Debt to Asset Ratio = 631,880.98 / 14,799,664.61 ≈ 0.04

Step 4: Calculate the Debt to Equity Ratio.
• Total Owner’s Equity = 14,167,783.63 
• Debt to Equity Ratio = 631,880.98 / 14,167,783.63 ≈ 0.04

Step 5: Calculate the Cash Flow to Debt Ratio.
Using net cash flow from operating activities:
• Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities = -1,368,775.90 
• Cash Flow to Debt Ratio = -1,368,775.90 / 631,880.98 ≈ -2.17

Thus, the solution is:

{
  "solution": {
    "Current Ratio": "15.65",
    "Quick Ratio": "15.12",
    "Debt to Asset Ratio": "0.04",
    "Debt to Equity Ratio": "0.04",
    "Cash Flow to Debt Ratio": "-2.17"
  }
}
